July 18, 2010: Fiction
PRIVATE, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) The
head of an investigation company pursues the murderer of his best friend’s wife.
SIZZLING SIXTEEN, by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin’s, $27.99.) The bounty
hunter Stephanie Plum comes to the aid of a cousin with gambling debts.
THE GIRL WHO KICKED THE HORNET’S NEST, by Stieg Larsson. (Knopf,
$27.95.) The third volume of a trilogy about a Swedish hacker and a journalist.
THE OVERTON WINDOW, by Glenn Beck. (Threshold Editions/Mercury Radio
Arts, $26.) A public relations executive and the woman he loves expose a
dangerous conspiracy.
THE HELP, by Kathryn Stockett. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam, $24.95.) A young white
woman and two black maids in 1960s Mississippi.
FOREIGN INFLUENCE, by Brad Thor. (Atria, $26.99.) The covert operative Scott
Harvath joins a new spy agency and investigates a bombing in Rome that killed
American students.
THE PASSAGE, by Justin Cronin. (Ballantine, $27.) More than a hundred years in
the future, a small group resists the vampires who have taken over North America.
THE LION, by Nelson DeMille. (Grand Central, $27.99.) John Corey, now a
federal agent, pursues a Libyan terrorist.
FAMILY TIES, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $28.) A woman who raised her
deceased sister’s three children must juggle their needs, her business and the
new man in her life.
ICE COLD, by Tess Gerritsen. (Ballantine, $26.) A group of friends are murdered
when they take refuge in a remote abandoned village in Wyoming.
IN THE NAME OF HONOR, by Richard North Patterson. (Holt, $26.) An Iraq
veteran shoots his commanding officer, who was married to a family friend.
WHIPLASH, by Catherine Coulter. (Putnam, 26.95.) The F.B.I. agents Dillon
Savich and Lacey Sherlock help investigate misdeeds at a pharmaceutical
company.
DEAD IN THE FAMILY, by Charlaine Harris. (Ace, $25.95.) Sookie Stackhouse is
exhausted in the aftermath of a Fae war.
THE THOUSAND AUTUMNS OF JACOB DE ZOET, by David Mitchell. (Random
House, $26.) Forbidden love in Edo-era Japan.
THE PARTICULAR SADNESS OF LEMON CAKE, by Aimee Bender. (Doubleday,
Non-Fiction
SH*T MY DAD SAYS, by Justin Halpern. (It Books/HarperCollins, $15.99.) A
coming-of-age memoir organized around the musings, purveyed on Twitter, of the
author’s father.
MEDIUM RAW, by Anthony Bourdain. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $26.99.) Bourdain
looks critically at changes in the food and restaurant cultures since the publication
of his “Kitchen Confidential” 10 years ago.
THE BIG SHORT, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $27.95.) The people who saw the
real estate crash coming and made billions from their foresight.
CHELSEA CHELSEA BANG BANG, by Chelsea Handler. (Grand Central,
$25.99.) More humorous personal essays from the comedian.
SPOKEN FROM THE HEART, by Laura Bush. (Scribner, $30.) A memoir from the
former first lady.
EMPIRE OF THE SUMMER MOON, by S. C. Gwynne. (Scribner, $27.50.) The
story of Quanah Parker, the last and greatest chief of the Comanches.
WAR, by Sebastian Junger. (Twelve, $26.99.) The intense lives of American
soldiers in a lethal corner of Afghanistan, by the author of “The Perfect Storm.”
HOME TEAM, by Sean Payton and Ellis Henican. (NAL, $24.95.) The head coach
of the New Orleans Saints describes the team’s Super Bowl victory, which raised
the city’s spirits four years after Hurricane Katrina.
OUTLIERS, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Why some people
succeed, from the author of “Blink.”
THE LAST STAND, by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Viking, $30.) Custer, Sitting Bull and
the Battle of the Little Bighorn.
UNCHARTED TERRITORI, by Tori Spelling with Hilary Liftin. (Gallery Books,
$25.) Humorous stories about juggling Hollywood work, marriage and motherhood,
from the author of “Mommywood” and star of “Tori & Dean: Home Sweet
Hollywood.”
THE IMMORTAL LIFE OF HENRIETTA LACKS, by Rebecca Skloot. (Crown,
$26.) The story of the woman whose cancer cells were cultured without her
permission in 1951 and have since supported a mountain of research.
CHANGE YOUR BRAIN, CHANGE YOUR BODY, by Daniel G. Amen. (Harmony,
$25.99.) Using the brain-body connection to lose weight and avoid depression.
BORN TO RUN, by Christopher McDougall. (Knopf, $24.95.) Secrets of distance
running from a Mexican Indian tribe.
